captions.text: Oh, you want a new video, do you?

I don&#39;t suppose it matters to you that I couldn&#39;t
play a new game last week because I was in

Los Angeles working my little English muffins
off at E3 so that you can all feel faintly

superior about not giving as much of a shit
about it?
Have you ever been to Los Angeles?

It&#39;s like a 7-11 with dodgy air conditioning
multiplied into a city.

And everyone drives like they learned on a
pair of roller skates.
So fuck it, I&#39;m staying in bed this week.

I&#39;m just going to review the last thing I
played on Steam, which happens to be Blood:

Fresh Supply, a recent port of Blood, the
classic mid to late 90&#39;s Build engine shooter

with a title that cuts refreshingly to the
nub of the matter.

At least until they stuck that Fresh Supply
bit on the end.
That&#39;s not even a pun, is it.

If they&#39;d called it Blood: Transfusion you&#39;d
get the connection but Fresh Supply could
be applied just as easily to tissues or underpants.
But anyway, let&#39;s talk about the Build engine.
The year is 1996.

No it isn&#39;t, Yahtz, it&#39;s twenty n- IT WAS
A RETROSPECTIVE DEVICE YOU FUCK.

The year is 1996 and Duke Nukem 3D comes out,
an FPS that threw out the mad idea that maybe

it could design its levels to look like actual
places that exist in real life.

Now, maybe that sounds obvious to you youngsters
who grew up throwing terrorists out of Burger

Kings in the latest Plodding Snorefare, but
this was coming off games like Doom and Quake,

highly playable and important games, god bless
&#39;em, but whose levels were all based around

samey labyrinths and traps and more monster
closets than an energy drink enthusiast&#39;s
bedroom the morning after a major game convention.

As tech improved it was Duke Nukem 3D leading
the charge for using the environment to set

the story, to enhance the effect of gameplay
by placing it somewhere familiar.

&quot;Why not set a first person shooter in a porn
theater?&quot; it asked.

&quot;Or in an adult bookstore or a strip club
or a porn studio?&quot;
&quot;Yes,&quot; said some other developers.

&quot;And perhaps also some locations that aren&#39;t
related to the sex industry.&quot;

&quot;Oh I don&#39;t think anyone would be interested
in that but you do you.&quot;

One of those other developers was Monolith,
who used the engine to make Blood, released
the following year.

Now, playing the Fresh Supply version today
you&#39;ll probably have a jolly good laugh at
the prerendered cinematics.

&quot;Ha ha, it looks like the preliminary storyboarding
for an episode of Reboot, what were you using

for graphics rendering, people of the 90s,
a fucking bathroom scale?&quot;

No, trust me, even at the time they looked
like absolute shit.
Still, they bring the story across.

Caleb, 19th century gunslinger with a voice
like Clint Eastwood if he made a living sucking

gravel out of the assholes of bats, is trying
to cozy up to the dark god Tchernobog when

Tchernobog decides he doesn&#39;t quite like the
colour of the sweater Caleb knitted for him

and promptly murders Caleb and all of his
mates.

Caleb then basically angries himself back
to life, climbs out of the grave with raging

morningwood and vows to slaughter all of Tchernobog&#39;s
minions, put all their bits in a break-up

box and shove it right up Tchernobog&#39;s galactic
arse.

With this remit in mind we proceed level by
level through a series of horror-themed early

20th century environments, all mysteriously
teeming with references to horror movies from

sixty or seventy years in the future, but
that&#39;s timeless deities for you.

Compared to modern video game protagonists,
who are usually highly bland but with some

attempt at moral complexity, Caleb is more
or less the precise opposite.
He&#39;s very un-bland and very un-complicated.

He just wants everyone to die while he screams
laughter at their fluttering remains.

And you lot made me go to E3, so who are you
to judge.
Blood is a product of its time.

It was originally shareware, so it has the
usual shareware problem - all its good levels

are in the first episode and by the end it&#39;s
one uninspired map full of reused assets probably
mocked up with old cereal boxes after another.

And playing 2.5D sprite shooters when you&#39;re
used to the full on photorealistic 3D models

of today is like breaking up with your supermodel
girlfriend and going back to wanking off over
erotic puppet shows.

But the 90s shooter is ever the place to go
for a bit of uninterrupted no-frills satisfying

combat, and Blood&#39;s is particularly visceral,
which is just as well, &#39;cos otherwise they

might have had to change the name to Little
Caleb&#39;s Adventures in Slumberland or something.

One thing I really miss about shooters from
this time is how the enemies actually had

some readable emotion and personality in their
appearance, it wasn&#39;t all faceless masks,

skull face demons or distant silhouettes peering
out from behind chest high walls.

You can really get a feel for the indignation
a cultist is feeling as you reduce the contents

of their torso to shredded sauerkraut with
both barrels.

Blood also, to my mind, possesses the best
&quot;person thrashing about on fire&quot; sprite of

any game of its type, and would have swept
the &quot;most likely to be blamed for an atrocity&quot;
awards had such a thing existed.

The sound design is a match, too, I never
get tired of the iconic jabbering of angry

cultists transitioning into a powerful shotgun
blast and then a prolonged scream so textured

you could almost break it down and pinpoint
the precise moments of regret he feels for
his misspent life.
On the whole, the core gameplay loop is great.

The porridge only starts dribbling into the
hair dryer when it comes to enemy AI.

For a start, all the flying enemies have this
weird habit of getting stuck on ceilings in

large rooms and fighting them is like trying
to recover your child&#39;s balloon from an overhead
power line.

But the real seam of bullshit running through
Blood like a chocolate brown skirting board

is that I don&#39;t think the developers realised
that the second enemy type in the first level
is the hardest one in the game.
Because they&#39;ve got hitscan weapons.

In the days before anyone could be arsed to
calculate such trifles as bullet velocity,

you&#39;d just pull the trigger and as long as
you have line of sight, the thing dies.

And when enemies had such weapons, common
courtesy dictated that they should at least

cough or say &quot;hello I&#39;m about to shoot you&quot;
before they shoot you so the player&#39;s got
time to duck or kill them first.
Blood&#39;s cultists never got that memo.

Step into their line of sight and your vital
parts will acquire holes like an argument

for alternative medicine under any amount
of scrutiny.
And these motherfuckers are everywhere.

In the higher difficult settings, which as
was usually the case in 90s shooters just

meant same dudes but twice as many of the
fuckers, one struggles to breathe in an atmosphere
of 40% lead.

Later on the game introduces new enemies that
are clearly supposed to be tougher, like the

gargoyles or the fat butchers with a weird
resemblance to Henry Kissinger, but none of

them have hitscan weapons so you just circle
strafe and shotgun and if anything fighting

them is a lovely holiday away from the twitchy
zero quarter hitscan safari.

I swear, increase the reaction time of the
cultists by, like, half a second and Blood&#39;s

overall difficulty drops like your mum&#39;s knickers
in the bathroom of a soup kitchen.

But these were the days when the shooter was
still young and the rules were still being

defined, and Blood wouldn&#39;t be the same if
you fixed its adorable baby giraffe on the
ice rink stumbling now.

The time for fixing it would have been the
sequel, but unfortunately Blood 2 came out

in the early days of full 3D, and if the baby
giraffe had been stumbling before, then early

3D made all its knees snap backwards as a
lighting gantry electrocuted its face.
